Issue 30

NFTs 4 Dummies

Installation View, Lorem, ispsum: Website Title © artists retain copyright

Non-Fungible Tokens

Reviewed by: Cris Gutierrez

https://jcristiangutierrez.github.io/

Keywords: Art, Digital Assets, Blockchain 3D art, Crypto art, Minting, Non-fungiblem,

Abstract

This article, Interview: Joel Slayton is just that, an interview with CADRE Founder Joel Slayton.

Article Body

Disciplines: Arts and Humanities: Art and Design; Illustration; Digital Humanities; Interactive Arts

In this article, I will be exploring the up-and-coming technologies of NFTs. For those unaware of what an NFT is, an NFT is a non-fungible token. The word non- fungible is the keyword in this acronym it basically means non-replaceable. Something that is non-fungible cannot be replicated and is irreplaceable a prime example of this in the real world. Would be the Vitruvian Man by Leonardo Da Vinci,  the  Vitruvian Man as we all know is a renowned anatomical drawing showcased in Venice, Italy. We all have an idea of what the Vitruvian Man looks like, which is the original copy and where it resides. This artwork is a once-in-a-lifetime piece, there is no replication that can amount to the value of the artwork or look anywhere close to it this is a one of one and we have authenticators that prove that. Thus making it non-fungible something that is fungible is the opposite of a non-fungible item, it is a product created in the mass, all look the same and are the same. An example of something that is fungible is a notebook, they all contain paper, roughly the same value as other notebooks, and are created in the masses. The token in the acronym refers to the digital asset you are receiving The origin of the first NFTs date back to the early 2010s by a digital artist named Kevin McCoy who minted the first NFT on the name coin blockchain. This new wave of technology was meant
